title: How to Clean an iPhone Charger Tip (Clean Your Lightning Cable)

steps.title: Gather a cotton swab, rubbing alcohol, a toothpick, a towel, and your charger.
steps.content: Gather a cotton swab, rubbing alcohol, a toothpick, a towel, and your charger. You might already have these items around the house, but if not, they can likely all be found at your local grocery store.

steps.title: Dip the end of the cotton swab in rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: Dip the end of the cotton swab in rubbing alcohol. [1] X Expert Source Linh Le Certified Mobile Repair Specialist Expert Interview. 10 February 2022. Use the rubbing alcohol with the highest alcohol percentage you can find. Ideally, it would be 99%. [2] X Research source Lower alcohol percentages mean there is more water in the solution, which can corrode your charger.

steps.title: Rub the charger tip with the cotton swab.
steps.content: Rub the charger tip with the cotton swab. When cleaning the tip of the charger, do not be afraid to apply some pressure. Often, chargers that fail due to corrosion have a visibly dirty fifth gold pin (when viewed with the metal tip below the white insulation). This is the most powerful circuit, so be sure to clean it as well as you can.

steps.title: Scrape the charger tip with the toothpick.
steps.content: Scrape the charger tip with the toothpick. After using the cotton swab, some spots may remain on the tip of your charger. Use a toothpick to remove any residue or corrosion while being careful of the gold connectors. If you damage a gold connector, the charger will stop working permanently, so do not scrape too hard!

steps.title: Dry the charger.
steps.content: Dry the charger. After drying the charger with your towel, wait as long as it takes to ensure there is no remaining liquid.

steps.title: Plug the charger into your phone.
steps.content: Plug the charger into your phone. If your phone begins charging, you have successfully cleaned your charger! Otherwise, if the charger still is not working, and the tip is still corroded, try cleaning it once more.

steps.title: Gather three cotton swabs, water, baking soda, liquid soap, white vinegar or lemon juice, a toothpick, a towel, and your charger.
steps.content: Gather three cotton swabs, water, baking soda, liquid soap, white vinegar or lemon juice, a toothpick, a towel, and your charger. These are relatively common household items, but if you cannot find any of them, they are almost certainly available at your local grocery store.

steps.title: De-grease the charger tip with soap and water.
steps.content: De-grease the charger tip with soap and water. Dip your cotton swab in some warm water with a little bit of soap, then rub the charger tip gently on each side. This will remove any residual grease from your hands. [3] X Research source If you are not sure what soap to use, dishwashing detergent or hand soap will work!

steps.title: Mix water, baking soda, and white vinegar or lemon juice.
steps.content: Mix water, baking soda, and white vinegar or lemon juice. You can measure out about half a cup of water, a teaspoon of baking soda, and a teaspoon of white vinegar or lemon juice. Warm water is preferable, but if you only have cold water, that is ok.

steps.title: Scrub the charger tip with the baking soda solution.
steps.content: Scrub the charger tip with the baking soda solution. Dip your second cotton swab in the solution you just made, then clean the lightning connector. Do not be afraid to apply pressure and clean it for several minutes, as this is necessary to remove the tougher build-up. Chargers that stop working due to corrosion often have a significant amount of buildup on the fifth gold pin (when viewed with the metal tip below the white insulation). This is the most powerful circuit, so be sure to clean it as well as you can.

steps.title: Remove residue and corrosion with the toothpick.
steps.content: Remove residue and corrosion with the toothpick. For especially resistant spots, lightly clean the charger tip with a toothpick. Be careful not to damage the gold pins, or your charger will stop working permanently!

steps.title: Clean the charger tip with water.
steps.content: Clean the charger tip with water. Dip your last cotton swab in warm water and rub both sides of the connector once more to remove the baking soda solution. Do not clean your charger tip with running water! If there is a leak in the cable connector housing, it will ruin the charger.

steps.title: Dry the charger.
steps.content: Dry the charger. Pat the connector dry with a towel, then wait two to three minutes to ensure it is completely dry.

steps.title: Plug the charger into your phone.
steps.content: Plug the charger into your phone. If your phone starts charging, the cleaning worked! Otherwise, if you can still see corrosion on the charger, try cleaning it once more.
